YouTube user Elman511 cracked open an over-sized egg that was laid by one of his hens. He found a standard-sized egg inside, along with yolk and white. The unusual occurrence is down to a counter-peristalsis contraction. This is when a second oocyte is released by the hen's ovary before the first egg has completely traveled through the oviduct. US researchers claim that exact prices of goods on eBay attract higher offers than round numbers. Items with precise prices attract higher offers than those with round numbers. They found that the reverberations of sound helps us locate the distance of a car passing round a bend or a person nearby. The research was conducted by scientists from the University of Connecticut. Greenstone is a small egg-shaped gadget that acts like a beacon, or a beacon. It helps messages move around so-called wireless mesh networks more than a mile. It uses a feature that launched in iOS 7 called Multipeer Connectivity Framework. It creates a wireless mesh network that connects phones to each other. It lets users send messages to people in close proximity that are in Bluetooth or Wi-Fi Direct. But there are limits to how far a message can travel in this way.

One-Touch-911 app was designed by researchers at Boston-based MIT. It works with emergency dispatchers in 135 countries. Each call is placed with GPS location, user details and medical information attached. If the user doesn't have signal on their network, the app lets them 'roam' onto another network.

A University of Nebraska researcher has revealed why stress is bad for you in a video. Limited periods of stress are good, as they release the hormone cortisol. This is useful in helping you recover from very tense situations. But too much will lower the immune system and make your bones fragile. The science of stress was explained by Dr Raychelle Burks from the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. She said prolonged periods of stress can inhibit the immune system.

Researchers in Tokyo, noted that rats flatten their ears and narrow their eyes when they are in pain. They also puff up their cheeks when they are in pain. To test the rodents' response to rats' pained expressions, they showed them the photos in a specially made cage. They found that rats spent less time in the room showing rodents in pain than they did in the other compartment showing rats with neutral expressions.

The Shoe that Grows has adjustable points at the front, sides and the back of the sandal to help it expand. Kenton Lee, from Nampa, Idaho, came up with the idea while working in Nairobi in Kenya. He saw children running around barefoot and in shoes several sizes too small. Pressure sensors in the shoe tells it when your foot is in position, triggering a tiny motor in the heel. When you want to take off the shoes, click your heels together twice and the motor will loosen the laces.

Norwich scientists have developed an adaptor for colour blindness. Eye2TV can be plugged into any HDMI port on a TV or a computer monitor. A remote control or app then adjusts the colour adjustment. It allows colour blind people to watch shows they otherwise couldn't. The team from the University of East Anglia in Norwich is seeking £100,000 ($150,000) of funding.

Spanish researchers say climate change impacted human migration. Until 1.4 million years ago it was too cold to inhabit southeast Spain. But then the climate warmed to 13°C (55°F) and became more humid. This enabled hominins - the distant ancestors. - to move to new regions. And it is believed that the earliest humans were a'slow-moving' species.

The study was conducted by scientists at Purdue University in Indiana. They were investigating how to reduce bird to aircraft collisions by keeping birds away from planes. Research showed that birds responded most to blue lights on planes. When the plane approached them with its lights off, their response slowed. But when it approached them with its lights off, their response. slowed. And they only became more alert when the lights were turned on. The researchers said runways could be synced with taxiing aircraft.

Tokyo researchers have proposed a laser system to attach to the ISS. It would be used to shoot down pieces of debris in Earth orbit. The system would have a range of 62 miles (100km) and could target things less than 0.4 inches (1cm) in size. It would then push space junk into Earth's atmosphere to burn up. The paper was published in Acta Astronautica.

Deep water gas hydrates in the Arctic are reservoirs for abiotic methane. The gas forms through a process called serpentinisation. It occurs when seawater reacts with hot mantle rocks exhumed along large faults within the seafloor. The reservoirs are secure, and scientists don't believe they will impact climate change. Instead, they say similar formations could be used to store methane, which can later be used as fuel.

University of Illinois scientists have created the first 3D simulation of merging black holes in a disk. It shows what happens when two supermassive black holes collide. The simulation was led by Dr Roman Gold, Dr Vasileios Paschachalidis, Dr Stuart Shapiro, Dr Milton Ruiz, Dr Zachariah Etienne, and Dr Harald Pfeiffer. The simulation was made using Einstein's general theory of relativity. It was used to predict two black holes will collide in just seven years.

Identical twins share 100 per cent of their genes, but it's impossible to tell which sibling a sample comes from. Gel contains platelet-rich plasma - a concentrated mix of substances in the blood. Made by taking a small amount of blood from a patient's arm. Processed in machine that spins the blood at high speed until it separated. Spinning the blood leaves behind the plasma and the platelets but in higher concentration. Gel, known as Magellan Bio-Bandage, will act as a barrier against infection.

Researchers from National Chung Hsing University in Taiwan found that the shape is determined by two competing groups of proteins. They converted lips into petals in two orchid species by reducing the activity of the L complex using gene silencing. They found that the L complex is a large and irregular modified petal. The Nanoheat Wireless Heated Mug is fitted with a rcharged battery, nanoheater and heat sleeve. It can maintain temperature of hot drinks at between 68°C and 71°C. The margins are between 68°C and 71°C (155 and 160°F) The mug weighs a little over one pound (454g) and can be charged wirelessly or using a traditional USB cord.

The 99-7% accurate BioSure HIV Self Test enables people to test themselves when. An estimated 26,000 people in the UK have HIV but are unaware of it. The kit uses a small amount of blood from a finger-prick sample to detect the presence of HIV antibodies. It gives a result in just 15 minutes.
